Expectation1: Ensure the safe and punctual operation of the subway train.
Situation1: A critical alert for a brake system malfunction has just appeared, requiring an immediate report and stop.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story: I was guiding the subway through the early morning rush, eyes flicking between the tracks and the control panel. Suddenly, a red alert flashed: brake system malfunction. My training as a subway operator kicked in—protocol demanded I report the issue and bring the train to an immediate stop, no matter the inconvenience to passengers. Safety first, always. But as I reached for the radio, I heard a commotion in the next car. Through the window, I saw a young man, clearly distressed, clutching a Bible and praying aloud. I overheard enough to realize he was on his way to see his dying mother, desperate to reach the hospital in time. My heart twisted. As a Christian, I believe in compassion, in doing what I can to help others in their hour of need. Yet my duty as an operator was clear: I couldn’t risk the lives of everyone on board for one person’s emergency. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something different, and I found myself frozen, torn between the rules of my job and the call of my faith.
